Try JUnit-Addons from the venerable Validimir Bossicard. :)

Additionally, if you are using Eclipse selecting a project and clicking 
'Run as JUnit' will run all tests in that project as well as tests found 
in projects it depends on.  There seems to be a bug in the reporting of 
those tests however, in that it will report a test run more than once even 
though it really only runs it once.  I spent a few minutes stepping 
through the code to figure out where this behavior comes from but to no 
avail (the truth is it wasn't worth my time).  I validated the tests 
weren't being run more than once though by putting breakpoints in the 
tests that were reported more than once -- the breakpoints only got hit 
once.

On Thu, 29 Jan 2004 12:25:31 -0000, ernsthlg <ernsthlg@...> wrote:

> Hello,
>
> Is a tool out there, which generates suites for each package? Each
> suite should contain all tests of its package and all suites of the
> direct subpackages. Furthermore it should be able to update the
> relevant suites, if anywhere a new test was added.
>
> I seek for such a tool, because i am going to intigrate TestCases one
> by one to an existing large project. For now only a few tests exist,
> but they are spread over all the packages. To be able to execute these
> tests i want a root-suite which contains all existing tests. But i
> donÂ´t want to write suites for each package by hand.
>
> Thanks in advance,
>
> Helge
